quotes.text: A man who has not passed through the inferno of his passions has never overcome them.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that confronting and experiencing one's deepest passions and struggles is essential for truly overcoming and understanding them.

quotes.text: Every form of addiction is bad, no matter whether the narcotic be alcohol or morphine or idealism.
quotes.explanation: Jung warns against any form of addiction, whether it is to substances or even seemingly positive ideals, as it can lead to a loss of balance and self-control.

quotes.text: The privilege of a lifetime is to become who you truly are.
quotes.explanation: This quote encourages individuals to embrace their true selves, seeing self-discovery and authenticity as the greatest achievements one can strive for in life.

quotes.text: I am not what happened to me, I am what I choose to become.
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes personal agency and resilience, asserting that one's identity and future are shaped by choices and actions rather than past experiences.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: One does not become enlightened by imagining figures of light, but by making the darkness conscious.
quotes.explanation: Enlightenment, according to Jung, comes not from wishful thinking but from confronting and understanding the darker aspects of oneself.

quotes.text: Everything that irritates us about others can lead us to an understanding of ourselves.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that our reactions to others often reflect our own unresolved issues, and understanding these reactions can provide insight into our own psyche.

quotes.text: As far as we can discern, the sole purpose of human existence is to kindle a light in the darkness of mere being.
quotes.explanation: Jung speaks to the existential quest for meaning, suggesting that humans are meant to bring understanding and illumination to the darker, unknown aspects of existence.

quotes.text: The greatest tragedy of the family is the unlived lives of the parents.
quotes.explanation: Jung highlights the impact of unfulfilled potential and dreams on family dynamics, suggesting that parents' unactualized lives can have profound effects on their children.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: Man needs difficulties; they are necessary for health.
quotes.explanation: Jung asserts that challenges and obstacles are essential for personal growth and psychological well-being, pushing individuals to develop resilience and strength.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: The pendulum of the mind oscillates between sense and nonsense, not between right and wrong.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that the human mind continuously shifts between rationality and irrationality, rather than strictly between correct and incorrect, highlighting the complexity of human thought.

quotes.text: There is no coming to consciousness without pain.
quotes.explanation: This quote emphasizes that self-awareness and growth often come through difficult and painful experiences, which are necessary for true understanding and consciousness.

quotes.text: The shoe that fits one person pinches another; there is no recipe for living that suits all cases.
quotes.explanation: Jung points out the individuality of human experience, suggesting that what works for one person may not work for another, and that each person must find their own path.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: A man who has not passed through the inferno of his passions has never overcome them.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that confronting and experiencing one's deepest passions and struggles is essential for truly overcoming and understanding them.

quotes.text: Every form of addiction is bad, no matter whether the narcotic be alcohol or morphine or idealism.
quotes.explanation: Jung warns against any form of addiction, whether it is to substances or even seemingly positive ideals, as it can lead to a loss of balance and self-control.

quotes.text: The privilege of a lifetime is to become who you truly are.
quotes.explanation: This quote encourages individuals to embrace their true selves, seeing self-discovery and authenticity as the greatest achievements one can strive for in life.

quotes.text: Who looks outside, dreams; who looks inside, awakes.
quotes.explanation: This quote underscores the importance of self-reflection and introspection. Jung suggests that true understanding and enlightenment come from looking within oneself rather than focusing solely on external realities.
quotes.reference: Collected Works of C.G. Jung, Volume 11: Psychology and Religion: West and East

quotes.text: Until you make the unconscious conscious, it will direct your life and you will call it fate.
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes the power of the unconscious mind and the need to bring unconscious thoughts and desires to conscious awareness to gain control over one's life and destiny.
quotes.reference: Aion: Researches into the Phenomenology of the Self

quotes.text: Your vision will become clear only when you look into your heart. Who looks outside, dreams; who looks inside, awakes.
quotes.explanation: Reiterating the importance of inner exploration, Jung asserts that clarity and true vision come from understanding one's inner self rather than relying on external validation.
quotes.reference: Collected Works of C.G. Jung, Volume 11: Psychology and Religion: West and East

quotes.text: The meeting of two personalities is like the contact of two chemical substances: if there is any reaction, both are transformed.
quotes.explanation: This quote highlights the profound impact of human interactions. Jung compares the interaction between people to a chemical reaction, emphasizing how such encounters can lead to significant personal transformation.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: Knowing your own darkness is the best method for dealing with the darknesses of other people.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that by understanding and accepting one's own flaws and darker aspects, one can better empathize with and support others in their struggles.

quotes.text: The privilege of a lifetime is to become who you truly are.
quotes.explanation: This quote encourages individuals to embrace their true selves, seeing self-discovery and authenticity as the greatest achievements one can strive for in life.

quotes.text: I am not what happened to me, I am what I choose to become.
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes personal agency and resilience, asserting that one's identity and future are shaped by choices and actions rather than past experiences.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: One does not become enlightened by imagining figures of light, but by making the darkness conscious.
quotes.explanation: Enlightenment, according to Jung, comes not from wishful thinking but from confronting and understanding the darker aspects of oneself.

quotes.text: Everything that irritates us about others can lead us to an understanding of ourselves.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that our reactions to others often reflect our own unresolved issues, and understanding these reactions can provide insight into our own psyche.

quotes.text: As far as we can discern, the sole purpose of human existence is to kindle a light in the darkness of mere being.
quotes.explanation: Jung speaks to the existential quest for meaning, suggesting that humans are meant to bring understanding and illumination to the darker, unknown aspects of existence.

quotes.text: The greatest tragedy of the family is the unlived lives of the parents.
quotes.explanation: Jung highlights the impact of unfulfilled potential and dreams on family dynamics, suggesting that parents' unactualized lives can have profound effects on their children.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: Man needs difficulties; they are necessary for health.
quotes.explanation: Jung asserts that challenges and obstacles are essential for personal growth and psychological well-being, pushing individuals to develop resilience and strength.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: The pendulum of the mind oscillates between sense and nonsense, not between right and wrong.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that the human mind continuously shifts between rationality and irrationality, rather than strictly between correct and incorrect, highlighting the complexity of human thought.

quotes.text: There is no coming to consciousness without pain.
quotes.explanation: This quote emphasizes that self-awareness and growth often come through difficult and painful experiences, which are necessary for true understanding and consciousness.

quotes.text: The shoe that fits one person pinches another; there is no recipe for living that suits all cases.
quotes.explanation: Jung points out the individuality of human experience, suggesting that what works for one person may not work for another, and that each person must find their own path.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: The shoe that fits one person pinches another; there is no recipe for living that suits all cases.
quotes.explanation: Jung highlights the uniqueness of individual experiences and the importance of personalizing one's approach to life. There is no one-size-fits-all solution to living; what works well for one person may not be suitable for another. This underscores the need for self-awareness and individualized approaches to personal and mental health.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: Your vision will become clear only when you look into your heart. Who looks outside, dreams; who looks inside, awakes.
quotes.explanation: Jung asserts that true clarity and understanding come from introspection rather than external observation. By turning inward and examining one's own heart and motivations, individuals can achieve a deeper level of self-awareness and enlightenment, as opposed to merely dreaming about possibilities seen outside of oneself.
quotes.reference: Collected Works of C.G. Jung, Volume 11: Psychology and Religion: West and East

quotes.text: Every form of addiction is bad, no matter whether the narcotic be alcohol or morphine or idealism.
quotes.explanation: Jung cautions against any form of addiction, whether it is to substances like alcohol and morphine or to seemingly noble concepts like idealism. Addictions of any kind can become detrimental, leading to a loss of balance and preventing individuals from living a healthy and integrated life.

quotes.text: The meeting of two personalities is like the contact of two chemical substances: if there is any reaction, both are transformed.
quotes.explanation: Jung uses the metaphor of a chemical reaction to describe the transformative potential of human interactions. When two people connect, they have the potential to influence and change each other profoundly, leading to mutual growth and transformation.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: Knowing your own darkness is the best method for dealing with the darknesses of other people.
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes the importance of self-awareness in dealing with others' flaws and challenges. By recognizing and understanding one's own dark aspects, individuals can better empathize with and support others, leading to more compassionate and effective relationships.

quotes.text: One does not become enlightened by imagining figures of light, but by making the darkness conscious.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that true enlightenment and self-awareness come from confronting and understanding the darker parts of the psyche. Rather than merely fantasizing about positive outcomes, it is essential to acknowledge and integrate the shadow aspects of the self.

quotes.text: The privilege of a lifetime is to become who you truly are.
quotes.explanation: Jung encourages individuals to embrace their authentic selves. The ultimate goal in life, according to him, is self-discovery and self-acceptance, leading to a fulfilling and genuine existence.

quotes.text: A man who has not passed through the inferno of his passions has never overcome them.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that it is necessary to confront and experience one's deepest passions and struggles in order to truly overcome and understand them. Avoiding these challenges prevents personal growth and mastery over one's inner demons.

quotes.text: Everything that irritates us about others can lead us to an understanding of ourselves.
quotes.explanation: Jung points out that our reactions to others often reflect our own unresolved issues. By examining what irritates us in others, we can gain insight into our own psyche and work towards resolving these internal conflicts.

quotes.text: The pendulum of the mind oscillates between sense and nonsense, not between right and wrong.
quotes.explanation: Jung highlights the complexity of human thought, suggesting that the mind constantly swings between rationality and irrationality, rather than strictly between right and wrong. This reflects the nuanced nature of human cognition and the challenges of maintaining a balanced perspective.

quotes.text: There is no coming to consciousness without pain.
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes that personal growth and self-awareness often come through difficult and painful experiences. These challenges are necessary for achieving true understanding and consciousness, leading to deeper insights and maturity.

quotes.text: Man needs difficulties; they are necessary for health.
quotes.explanation: Jung asserts that facing challenges and difficulties is essential for personal growth and psychological well-being. These obstacles push individuals to develop resilience, strength, and a deeper understanding of themselves.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: As far as we can discern, the sole purpose of human existence is to kindle a light in the darkness of mere being.
quotes.explanation: Jung speaks to the existential quest for meaning, suggesting that humans are meant to bring understanding and illumination to the darker, unknown aspects of existence. This pursuit of knowledge and self-awareness is seen as the fundamental purpose of life.

quotes.text: The greatest tragedy of the family is the unlived lives of the parents.
quotes.explanation: Jung highlights the impact of unfulfilled potential and dreams on family dynamics. When parents do not pursue their own passions and aspirations, it can lead to a sense of regret and lost opportunities, which may negatively affect their children and family relationships.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: A man who has not passed through the inferno of his passions has never overcome them.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that it is necessary to confront and experience one's deepest passions and struggles in order to truly overcome and understand them. Avoiding these challenges prevents personal growth and mastery over one's inner demons.

quotes.text: People will do anything, no matter how absurd, to avoid facing their own souls.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that individuals often go to great lengths to avoid confronting their own inner issues and truths. This avoidance can lead to irrational behavior, highlighting the importance of self-reflection and facing one's own soul for genuine personal growth.

quotes.text: In all chaos there is a cosmos, in all disorder a secret order.
quotes.explanation: Jung highlights the idea that beneath apparent chaos and disorder lies a hidden structure or order. This perspective can provide comfort and insight, suggesting that there is meaning and organization even in life's most confusing moments.
quotes.reference: Collected Works of C.G. Jung, Volume 9 (Part 1): The Archetypes and The Collective Unconscious

quotes.text: The most terrifying thing is to accept oneself completely.
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes the profound difficulty and fear associated with fully accepting oneself, including one's flaws and darker aspects. This acceptance is crucial for true self-understanding and personal integration.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: A dream that is not understood remains a mere occurrence; understood, it becomes a living experience.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that dreams hold valuable insights into the unconscious mind. By understanding and interpreting dreams, they can become meaningful experiences that contribute to personal growth and self-awareness.
quotes.reference: Collected Works of C.G. Jung, Volume 8: Structure & Dynamics of the Psyche

quotes.text: The healthy man does not torture others – generally it is the tortured who turn into torturers.
quotes.explanation: Jung posits that those who inflict harm on others often do so because of their own unresolved pain and suffering. This insight fosters empathy and understanding, emphasizing the importance of addressing one's own wounds to prevent harm to others.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: We cannot change anything unless we accept it. Condemnation does not liberate, it oppresses.
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes the power of acceptance in facilitating change. By accepting reality and oneself, individuals can achieve liberation and transformation, whereas condemnation only leads to further oppression and stagnation.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: The meeting of two personalities is like the contact of two chemical substances: if there is any reaction, both are transformed.
quotes.explanation: Jung uses the metaphor of a chemical reaction to describe the transformative potential of human interactions. When two people connect, they have the potential to influence and change each other profoundly, leading to mutual growth and transformation.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: Who has fully realized that history is not contained in thick books but lives in our very blood?
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes the idea that history is not merely a record of past events but is deeply ingrained in our very being. This quote encourages a deeper understanding of how historical experiences shape and influence us on a fundamental level.
quotes.reference: The Collected Works of C.G. Jung, Volume 8: Structure & Dynamics of the Psyche

quotes.text: The creative mind plays with the objects it loves.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that creativity stems from a place of love and playful engagement. The creative process is driven by an intrinsic passion and affection for the objects or subjects one works with.

quotes.text: Every form of addiction is bad, no matter whether the narcotic be alcohol or morphine or idealism.
quotes.explanation: Jung warns against all forms of addiction, whether to substances or ideas. Such dependencies can be detrimental to one's mental health and overall balance, highlighting the need for moderation and self-awareness.

quotes.text: Man needs difficulties; they are necessary for health.
quotes.explanation: Jung asserts that facing challenges and difficulties is essential for personal growth and psychological well-being. These obstacles push individuals to develop resilience, strength, and a deeper understanding of themselves.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: The privilege of a lifetime is to become who you truly are.
quotes.explanation: Jung encourages individuals to embrace their authentic selves. The ultimate goal in life, according to him, is self-discovery and self-acceptance, leading to a fulfilling and genuine existence.

quotes.text: The pendulum of the mind oscillates between sense and nonsense, not between right and wrong.
quotes.explanation: Jung highlights the complexity of human thought, suggesting that the mind constantly swings between rationality and irrationality, rather than strictly between right and wrong. This reflects the nuanced nature of human cognition and the challenges of maintaining a balanced perspective.

quotes.text: There is no coming to consciousness without pain.
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes that personal growth and self-awareness often come through difficult and painful experiences. These challenges are necessary for achieving true understanding and consciousness, leading to deeper insights and maturity.

quotes.text: The least of things with a meaning is worth more in life than the greatest of things without it.
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes the importance of meaning and purpose. Even small things imbued with significance are more valuable than grand but meaningless achievements.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: A man who has not passed through the inferno of his passions has never overcome them.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that it is necessary to confront and experience one's deepest passions and struggles in order to truly overcome and understand them. Avoiding these challenges prevents personal growth and mastery over one's inner demons.

quotes.text: Knowing your own darkness is the best method for dealing with the darknesses of other people.
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes the importance of self-awareness in dealing with others' flaws and challenges. By recognizing and understanding one's own dark aspects, individuals can better empathize with and support others, leading to more compassionate and effective relationships.

quotes.text: Thinking is difficult, that’s why most people judge.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that thoughtful reflection requires effort, which is why many people opt for quick judgments instead. This quote encourages deeper contemplation and understanding rather than superficial assessments.

quotes.text: You are what you do, not what you say you'll do.
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes the importance of actions over words. True character and intentions are revealed through one's actions rather than mere promises or statements.

quotes.text: Shame is a soul-eating emotion.
quotes.explanation: Jung identifies shame as a destructive emotion that can erode one's sense of self and well-being. Addressing and overcoming shame is crucial for mental and emotional health.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: Show me a sane man and I will cure him for you.
quotes.explanation: Jung challenges the concept of normalcy and sanity, suggesting that everyone has complexities and irrationalities. This quote invites a reevaluation of what it means to be 'sane' and encourages acceptance of human imperfection.
quotes.reference: Collected Works of C.G. Jung, Volume 16: The Practice of Psychotherapy

quotes.text: Where wisdom reigns, there is no conflict between thinking and feeling.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that true wisdom harmonizes thought and emotion. When wisdom is present, there is a balance between rational thinking and emotional experience, leading to a more integrated and peaceful state of mind.

quotes.text: The least of things with a meaning is worth more in life than the greatest of things without it.
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes the importance of meaning and purpose. Even small things imbued with significance are more valuable than grand but meaningless achievements.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: What you resist, persists.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that resisting or denying difficult emotions or situations often makes them more persistent. Acceptance and confrontation are essential for overcoming and resolving internal conflicts.

quotes.text: We cannot change anything until we accept it. Condemnation does not liberate, it oppresses.
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes the power of acceptance in creating change. Condemning or rejecting parts of oneself or reality only leads to further oppression, whereas acceptance can lead to liberation and transformation.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: Even a happy life cannot be without a measure of darkness, and the word 'happiness' would lose its meaning if it were not balanced by sadness.
quotes.explanation: Jung highlights the duality of human experience, suggesting that happiness and sadness are interdependent. The presence of some darkness and sadness gives depth and meaning to happiness, making it more appreciable.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: Where love rules, there is no will to power; and where power predominates, there love is lacking. The one is the shadow of the other.
quotes.explanation: Jung contrasts love and power, suggesting that they are mutually exclusive forces. Where love is present, there is no desire to dominate, and where power seeks to dominate, love is absent. Each reveals the shadow of the other, highlighting the need for balance and the dangers of prioritizing power over love.
quotes.reference: Collected Works of C.G. Jung, Volume 10: Civilization in Transition

quotes.text: To ask the right question is already half the solution of a problem.
quotes.explanation: Jung underscores the importance of asking the right questions in problem-solving. Formulating a good question directs attention and thought in productive ways, often leading to clearer and more effective solutions.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: Thinking is difficult, that’s why most people judge.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that thoughtful reflection requires effort, which is why many people opt for quick judgments instead. This quote encourages deeper contemplation and understanding rather than superficial assessments.

quotes.text: The beginning is the most important part of the work.
quotes.explanation: This quote emphasizes the importance of starting any task or project well, as the beginning sets the tone and foundation for everything that follows.

quotes.text: Wise men speak because they have something to say; fools because they have to say something.
quotes.explanation: Plato distinguishes between the thoughtful communication of the wise and the unnecessary chatter of fools, highlighting the value of meaningful speech.

quotes.text: The measure of a man is what he does with power.
quotes.explanation: This quote reflects on the true nature of a person being revealed when they are given power, emphasizing integrity and moral character in leadership.

quotes.text: The greatest wealth is to live content with little.
quotes.explanation: Plato suggests that true wealth lies in being satisfied with what one has, rather than constantly seeking more, thus finding contentment in simplicity.

quotes.text: Ignorance, the root and stem of all evil.
quotes.explanation: This quote highlights the idea that ignorance is the fundamental cause of wrongdoing, stressing the importance of knowledge and awareness.

quotes.text: Courage is knowing what not to fear.
quotes.explanation: Plato defines true courage as understanding which fears are rational and which are not, encouraging wise and discerning bravery.

quotes.text: At the touch of love, everyone becomes a poet.
quotes.explanation: This quote expresses the idea that love has the power to inspire creativity and beauty in everyone, revealing deep emotions and artistry.

quotes.text: The direction in which education starts a man will determine his future life.
quotes.explanation: Plato underscores the profound impact of early education on an individual's future, emphasizing the importance of proper guidance and learning from a young age.

quotes.text: An empty vessel makes the loudest sound, so they that have the least wit are the greatest babblers.
quotes.explanation: Plato observes that those with little knowledge often speak the most, drawing a parallel between an empty vessel making more noise than a full one.

quotes.text: The soul takes nothing with her to the next world but her education and her culture.
quotes.explanation: This quote highlights the enduring value of education and cultural development, suggesting that these are the only true possessions that follow us beyond life.

quotes.text: There are three classes of men: lovers of wisdom, lovers of honor, and lovers of gain.
quotes.explanation: Plato categorizes people based on their primary pursuits, identifying philosophers, warriors, and businessmen, each motivated by different desires.

quotes.text: He who is not a good servant will not be a good master.
quotes.explanation: This quote suggests that effective leadership requires the experience and humility gained from serving others, highlighting the importance of empathy and understanding.

quotes.text: Knowledge which is acquired under compulsion obtains no hold on the mind.
quotes.explanation: Plato argues that learning forced upon someone is ineffective, as true understanding and retention require genuine interest and voluntary engagement.

quotes.text: Human behavior flows from three main sources: desire, emotion, and knowledge.
quotes.explanation: Plato identifies the primary drivers of human actions, emphasizing the interplay between desires, emotions, and knowledge in shaping behavior.

quotes.text: Good actions give strength to ourselves and inspire good actions in others.
quotes.explanation: This quote underscores the ripple effect of positive actions, suggesting that doing good not only empowers us but also motivates others to act similarly.

quotes.text: The old have a greater sense of calm and freedom when the passions relax their hold.
quotes.explanation: This highlight reflects on the benefits of aging, suggesting that as one grows older, they may find more peace and liberation from the intense emotions and desires of youth.
quotes.original_text: For certainly old age has a great sense of calm and freedom; when the passions relax their hold, then, as Sophocles says, we are freed from the grasp not of one mad master only, but of many.

quotes.text: The greatest blessing of wealth is that it frees us from doing injustice and enables us to depart to the next world without fear.
quotes.explanation: This passage suggests that the true value of wealth lies not in luxury, but in the ability to live honestly and face death without regret or fear of punishment.
quotes.original_text: And the great blessing of riches, I do not say to every man, but to a good man, is, that he has had no occasion to deceive or to defraud others, either intentionally or unintentionally; and when he departs to the world below he is not in any apprehension about offerings due to the gods or debts which he owes to men.

quotes.text: Is it just to give back to a person what is owed if they are not in their right mind?
quotes.explanation: This question challenges simplistic notions of justice, suggesting that context and consequences must be considered when determining right action.
quotes.original_text: Suppose that a friend when in his right mind has deposited arms with me and he asks for them when he is not in his right mind, ought I to give them back to him? No one would say that I ought or that I should be right in doing so, any more than they would say that I ought always to speak the truth to one who is in his condition.

quotes.text: The art of payment has the special function of giving pay, but we do not confuse this with other arts.
quotes.explanation: This passage distinguishes between the intrinsic function of an art or skill and the payment received for it, emphasizing that payment is not the primary purpose of any craft.
quotes.original_text: And the art of payment has the special function of giving pay: but we do not confuse this with other arts, any more than the art of the pilot is to be confused with the art of medicine, because the health of the pilot may be improved by a sea voyage.

quotes.text: No artist or ruler aims at their own advantage, but at the advantage of their subject.
quotes.explanation: This principle argues that true professionals and leaders should prioritize the welfare of those they serve over their personal gain.
quotes.original_text: I conceived that the art of the ruler, considered as ruler, whether in a state or in private life, could only regard the good of his flock or subjects; whereas you seem to think that the rulers in states, that is to say, the true rulers, like being in authority.

quotes.text: The best rulers are those who are reluctant to govern.
quotes.explanation: This paradoxical idea suggests that those best suited to rule are those who do not seek power for its own sake, but accept it as a duty.
quotes.original_text: The truth is that the State in which the rulers are most reluctant to govern is always the best and most quietly governed, and the State in which they are most eager, the worst.

quotes.text: Good people are unwilling to rule for money or honor, but to avoid the penalty of being ruled by someone worse.
quotes.explanation: This passage explains why virtuous individuals might accept leadership roles, not for personal gain, but to prevent less capable or ethical people from taking power.
quotes.original_text: And for this reason, money and honour have no attraction for them; good men do not wish to be openly demanding payment for governing and so to get the name of hirelings, nor by secretly helping themselves out of the public revenues to get the name of thieves. And not being ambitious they do not care about honour. Wherefore necessity must be laid upon them, and they must be induced to serve from the fear of punishment.

quotes.text: The worst evil for a state is that which tears it apart and makes it many instead of one.
quotes.explanation: This idea emphasizes the importance of unity in a state, suggesting that division and factionalism are the greatest threats to its stability and success.
quotes.original_text: Can there be any greater evil than discord and distraction and plurality where unity ought to reign? or any greater good than the bond of unity?

quotes.text: A state arises because no individual is self-sufficient; we all have many wants.
quotes.explanation: This passage explains the fundamental reason for the formation of societies, based on the interdependence of individuals with diverse needs and skills.
quotes.original_text: A State, I said, arises, as I conceive, out of the needs of mankind; no one is self-sufficing, but all of us have many wants.

quotes.text: The creation of a luxurious state may help us see how justice and injustice originate in societies.
quotes.explanation: This suggestion implies that examining a more complex, affluent society might reveal the roots of justice and injustice more clearly than a simpler one.
quotes.original_text: I have no objection; for I suspect that many will not be satisfied with the simpler way of life. They will be for adding sofas, and tables, and other furniture; also dainties, and perfumes, and incense, and courtesans, and cakes, all these not of one sort only, but in every variety; we must go beyond the necessaries of which I was at first speaking. Now I reflect, that this is not merely the growth of a State, but of a luxurious State; and possibly there is no harm in this, for in such a State we shall be more likely to see how justice and injustice originate.
